00020 
00021 //Macro for class members with getters and setters! Thanks DCoder!
00022 // Sod it, primitive data types are too annoying to get() all the time
00023 /*
00024         protected:\
00025                 type name;\
00026 */
00027 
00028 #define PROPERTY(type,name) \
00029         public: \
00030                 type name; \
00031         public:\
00032                 type get_ ## name() \
00033                         { return name; }\
00034                 void set_ ## name(type value)\
00035                         { name = value; }
00036 
00037 #define PROPERTY_PTR(type,name)\
00038         public: \
00039                 type name;\
00040         public:\
00041                 type get_ ## name() \
00042                         { return name; }\
00043                 void set_ ## name(type value)\
00044                         { name = value; } \
00045                 type* lea_ ## name() \
00046                         { return &name; }
00047 
00048 //readonly version
00049 #define PROPERTY_READONLY(type,name)\
00050         protected:\
00051                 type name;\
00052         public:\
00053                 const type get_ ## name() \
00054                         { return name; }
00055 
00056 //struct or class instances
00057 #define PROPERTY_STRUCT(type,name)\
00058         public: \
00059                 type name;\
00060         public:\
00061                 type* get_ ## name() \
00062                         { return &name; }\
00063                 void set_ ## name(type* value)\
00064                         { name = *value; }
00065 
00066 //readonly
00067 #define PROPERTY_READO_STRUCT(type,name)\
00068         protected:\
00069                 type name;\
00070         public:\
00071                 type* _ ## name() \
00072                         { return &name; }
00073 
00074 //Arrays
00075 #define PROPERTY_ARRAY(type,name,length)\
00076         public: \
00077                 type name[length];\
00078         public:\
00079                 type get_ ## name(int n)\
00080                         { return name[n]; }\
00081                 void set_ ## name(int n, type value)\
00082                         { name[n] = value; }
00083 
00084 //Arrays of struct or class instances
00085 #define PROPERTY_STRUCT_ARRAY(type,name,length)\
00086         public: \
00087                 type name[length];\
00088         public:\
00089                 type* get_ ## name(int n)\
00090                         { return &name[n]; }\
00091                 void set_ ## name(int n, type value)\
00092                         { name[n] = value; }
00093 
00094 //Strings
00095 #define PROPERTY_STRING(name,length)\
00096         public: \
00097                 char name[length];\
00098         public:\
00099                 char* get_ ## name()\
00100                         { return name; }\
00101                 void  set_ ## name(const char* value)\
00102                         { strncpy(name, value, length); }
00103 
00104 #define PROPERTY_UNICODE(name,length)\
00105         public: \
00106                 wchar_t name[length];\
00107         public:\
00108                 wchar_t* get_ ## name()\
00109                         { return name; }\
00110                 void  set_ ## name(const wchar_t* value)\
00111                         { wcsncpy(name, value, length); }
00112 
00113 //Not gettable/settable members
00114 #define PROTECTED_PROPERTY(type,name)\
00115         protected:\
00116                 type name;
00117 
00118 // following westwood's style
00119 #define VALIDTAG(str) \
00120         (strcmpi("<none>", str) && strcmpi("none", str))
00121 
00122 /*
00123 Operation: The Cleansing
00124 
00125 These two replace a function's implementation.
00126 
00127 R0 is used for functions which return a numeric value or a pointer.
00128 RX is for functions without a return type.
00129 Functions that return struct instances will have to be written manually.
00130 
00131 I chose short names to keep things clean.
00132 
00133 Example usage:
00134 virtual int foo(int bar) R0;
00135 virtual void alla(double malla) RX;
00136 */
00137 
00138 #define R0 {return 0;}
00139 #define RX {}
00140 
00141 #endif
